title: Chichester Canal Walk Route

images.title: mike lis / The Chichester Canal
images.caption: Looking towards the Cathedral in the distance on a fine late spring morning. The canal (originally part of the Portsmouth and Arundel Canal) was opened in 1822 and took three years to build.

images.title: Janine Forbes / Chichester Canal
images.caption: Looking NNW from Poyntz Bridge, Hunston. Chichester Cathedral (SU8604) can be seen on the horizon. The canal, with a total length of 4 miles, was opened in 1822 and could accommodate boats up to 150 tons. Commercial use of the canal came to an end in 1906. It has now been restored and is an important habitat for wildlife. The former towpath on the west bank of the canal is a footpath from Chichester city to Chichester Marina.

images.title: Simon Carey / Houseboats on the Chichester Canal
images.caption: Houseboats on the Chichester Canal. Each have their own individual ferry to get you to their front door. Looking west at the top of the square.

images.title: Simon Carey / Chichester Canal Basin
images.caption: Chichester Canal Basin. Originally just a branch of a canal that was to link Portsmouth with London, Chichester is now the terminus of the restored canal that begins at Birdham. This view looks north taking in a festive visitor.

images.title: Cutfield Bridge by N Chadwick, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Cutfield Bridge.

images.title: Basher Eyre / Cyclist heading towards Crosbie Bridge
images.caption: Cyclist heading towards Crosbie Bridge

images.title: Basher Eyre / Hunston Bridge
images.caption: Hunston Bridge. By stopping at the Hunston Bridge you can look back and enjoy the view of the canal against a backdrop of Chichester Cathedral and the Downs – the same view painted by JMW Turner in 1828.

images.title: Chichester Marina by N Chadwick, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Chichester Marina

description: Enjoy a lovely waterside stroll along the Chichester Canal on this easy walk in Sussex. The walk begins in the centre of Chichester (near the train station and cathedral) following the canal towpath to Chichester Marina and Birdham where there are some great boats to see. Although this is categorised as a walking route, cyclists can also enjoy the first section of the towpath from Chichester to Hunston. The canal is great for wildlife so keep your eyes peeled for birds such as moorhens, coots, heron, kingfisher, whitethroat, common sandpiper, spotted flycatcher and woodpecker. You may also see foxes, deer and dragonflies as you may your way along the path. You can turn it into a longer circular walk by heading north along the coastal path to Apuldram. To extend your walking in the area you could head south and enjoy a lovely coastal walk at the RSPB Pagham Harbour reserve. You could also visit the nearby Chidham Peninsula and enjoy great views of Chichester Harbour . In the city itself the Chichester Walls Walk is a great way of learning about the fascinating Roman history of the area.
